reviewText: Not as good as the original, but very good nevertheless.

this was a fantastic sequel.  all the charactersfrom season

Chancer, Series 2, (1991). The raw young smolderingly sexy Clive Owen had his first television series lead in this show, and it was the breakout part that made him a star. It is a neo-noir British crime drama, in color, and was originally made by Central for ITV. It was a ratings smash in the United Kingdom, and has been compared to DALLAS, DYNASTY and TWIN PEAKS. In it, Owen played Stephen Crane, a rude and arrogant, smooth-talking, shady investment analyst; ingenious, unprincipled, and charming: a swindler and a thief who'd been fired by an investment bank after one dodgy deal too many. This second series arrives in a box set of two volumes comprising seven episodes of approximately 350 minutes. Unfortunately, the set does not include subtitles, and many, who live on my side of the pond, including me, will find that, though they can usually follow the plot, they will miss much of the dialog, and some of the plot's finer points. Acorn, the manufacturers, also warns that due to the age of these programs and the improved resolution of the DVD media, viewers may notice occasional flaws in the image and audio that they could not correct. Owen, of course, has long since achieved film stardom, see Children of Men,Croupier, or his Oscar-nominated turn in Closer. He opens Series 2 as conman Derek Love, a.k.a. Stephen Crane, just released from prison and scheming to save not only the estate of his former co-worker/friend/competitor/romantic rival, Piers Garfield-Ward (Simon Shepherd). The two men are also cooperating in efforts to save Joseph, the orphaned child of their mutual late love, Joanna Franklyn, who helpfully reappears throughout in flashbacks and dreams. ( She is played by blond of the decade Susannah Harker, House of Cards Trilogy: The Original UK Series Remastered). They are struggling to keep the child from the sole custody of his grandfather, the great City financial wiz Tom Franklyn, as played by the energetic Peter Vaughan (Death at a Funeral ,The Remains Of The Day). Series 2 is, like series 1, packed with plot twists and double/triple crosses; it features returning faces from Series 1 as well as a new romantic interest played by Leslie Lombard (The House of Eliott - Complete Collection), a woman on the run from her own questionable past. The episodes are: Disc 1 EPISODE 1 Jo Derek Love, newly released from prison and casting aside his Stephen Crane alias, immediately begins searching for his former love, Jo. But she flees to Piers's country estate with her baby and is joined by her newfound friend Anna, a woman on the lam herself. EPISODE 2 Ashes Piers assumes that he is baby Joseph's father, and prepares to battle Franklyn for custody of the child. Meanwhile, Dex enlists Anna to help scam Franklyn's newly opened casino. But Anna has her own designs on the money. EPISODE 3 Secrets Dex and Piers hatch a plot to turn Piers' family estate Winterleigh into a private gambling club in an attempt to raise funds to refurbish it, First, though, they need a list of well-heeled likely club patrons--which they aim to get from Franklyn's casino. By any means necessary. EPISODE 4 Remembrance Anna finds a series of Nativity drawings. Possibly by famous German artist Albrecht Dürer. Selling them might finance further work on Winterleigh, but their provenance remains mysterious. Meanwhile, Dex antagonizes the estate's former caretaker--with unfortunate results. Disc 2 EPISODE 5 Blood With money and membership records stolen from Franklyn, Winterleigh's gambling club gets off to a smashing start, and Franklyn vows revenge. Then, just as the results of baby Joseph's paternity test come in, Anna uncovers Jo's long-lost letter revealing the child's true father. EPISODE 6 Fall Roman, Anna's ex-lover secures his release from an African prison and begins tracking her down, bent on vengeance. And, with bankers threatening to pull financing for Franklyn's proposed industrial park, the embattled businessman bargains for Dex's help. EPISODE 7 Sacrifice Roman kidnaps Jimmy Blake, as played by Leslie Phillips (I Love You Phillip Morris), former boss of both Dex and Piers. Roman then kidnaps baby Joseph and Anna. After he's demanded ransom, Roman phones Dex, saying ominously, "Come to the Holy City--alone. You can be Abraham. I'll be God." The series is, of course, a perfect vehicle for the young Owen, whose star quality shines through. He is backed by a solid ensemble providing good support. In fact, the acting throughout is sufficient; and the production, lavish. However, if you can't tell, the series' plots, although compelling, are somewhat over the top. It is deeply rooted in the go-go, greed is good 1980's and 1990s, and somewhat dated. If, in the grim years that followed the breaking of this bubble, you have been missing tales of predatory investment bankers and asset stripping - and you have very sharp hearing -- this series may be for you.

Hi I also found Chancer a very good series, to me it was like a series of cat and mouse, with a very excellent story line. I love Clive Owens and as far as I am concern he has never let me down with his movies, or Tv Series.
Wish there could be a series 3
Chancer has many great actors which also makes this series a must to watch. I hope other also get the pleasure of sitting back and relaxing on a cold day and being entertained by the best. Thank you Amazon another hit for me.

NOt as good as season one but very watcheable. Clive Owen does do this character very well as do the others with their roles.

Chancer is a wonderful series made before Clive Owen was discovered by American audiences.  The character he plays here is amoral, dishonest, and greedy.  In short, a really compelling character in a great series.

Clive is excellent in this british drama series, enjoyed the first chancer series, recently purchased the second series, i found the storylines more dark and compeling, i highly recommemd it, this was the catalyst for cementing clives acting career.

The second year in the Chancer series is even better than the first year.
It is disappointing in that it has only has four episodes.  The characters are brilliantly played.  Clive Owen just keeps getting better with each performance.
Starts slow, many character to become aquainted with, but by third episode I was hooked. Writing improved, intriging and is a must see.
